AlterwardS, when Ι was preparing to go into the bath, twenty days from the first attack of my illness, perceiving on a sudden the physicians whispering together, Ι inquired what they were saying. They replied‚ Ι might possibly bathe with safety‚ however, they were not without some suspicion of hazard. “What need,” said Ι, “of doing it at all?'' And thus with great complacency, Ι gave up the expected pleasure of bathing, and abstained from the bath with the same inward and outward composure Ι was going to enter it. Ι mention this, not only in order to enforce my advice by example, but also that this letter may be a sort of pledge binding me to ' persevere in the same abstinence for the future. Farewell.

Anu you not inconsistent with yourself, when you assure me you have no intermission from business and yet at the same time express an earnest desire to see my works; upon which even the idle will scarce bestow some of their useless hours? Ι will not then break in upon your affairs during this busy summer season; but when the return of winter shall make it reasonable to suppose that your eveningS, at least„ may be disengaged‚ Ι will look over my trilles for something worth showing you. ln the meanwhile, Ι shall be well satisfied, if my letters are not troublesome‚ as Ι suspect they are, and therefore shorten them.
